issue.title: ANY23-441 Upgrade JSoup version from 1.11.3 to 1.12.1

repository.name: any23
repository.description: Apache Anything To Triples (Any23) is a library, a web service and a command line tool that extracts structured data in RDF format from a variety of Web documents.

issue.body:
This ugprade fixes the ArrayOutOfBoundException described in [ANY23-441](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/ANY23/issues/ANY23-441).

I did not add a test because I failed to found a minimal reproduction case.

body: @jhy To add to what @panthony was saying, in Any23, we're using Jsoup to strip html tags from an arbitrary byte stream (for charset detection) by decoding as ISO-8859-1, stripping tags, and then re-encoding as ISO-8859-1 (even though the actual charset may _not_ be ISO-8859-1). During this process, we definitely wouldn't want exceptions to be raised for null bytes.

Also, this "feature" honestly seems a bit out of scope for jsoup... especially given the risk of false positives. If I actually needed something like this, I'd rather implement my own binary detection mechanism and then simply pass in a `java.io.FilterReader` that throws according to a strategy tuned to my own needs. (Or implement a similar behavior at the charset detection level, using a more comprehensive library such as Tika, which is specifically written for stuff like this.) 

That being said, obviously the biggest problem here is that there's no way to opt out.

@HansBrende thanks for the feedback. I agree, this needs to be reworked. I don't know that we want to bring in Tikka, want to keep the depencies low. My thought is, if we leave it in, to add it to the section where the Connection is tested for MIME type. If there is no MIME type, try and determine if it is binary. Still, that would benefit from an override option, so it might be simplest to remove entirely.

issue.title: Vertsion 1.12.1 bug in CharacterReader

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This is a duplicate issue or root-cause of another issue

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.title: Underlying input stream returned zero bytes

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A confirmed bug, that we should fix

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
```
Caused by org.jsoup.c: java.io.IOException: Underlying input stream returned zero bytes
       at org.jsoup.parser.CharacterReader.bufferUp(CharacterReader.java:60)
       at org.jsoup.parser.CharacterReader.(CharacterReader.java)
       at org.jsoup.parser.CharacterReader.(CharacterReader.java)
       at org.jsoup.parser.TreeBuilder.defaultSettings(TreeBuilder.java:35)
       at org.jsoup.parser.HtmlTreeBuilder.initialiseParse(HtmlTreeBuilder.java:66)
       at org.jsoup.parser.TreeBuilder.parse(TreeBuilder.java:44)
       at org.jsoup.parser.Parser.parseInput(Parser.java:39)
       at org.jsoup.helper.DataUtil.parseInputStream(DataUtil.java:151)
       at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection$Response.parse(HttpConnection.java:832)
       at org.jsoup.helper.HttpConnection.get(HttpConnection.java:289)
```

There isn't much information I can offer here.
This is with JSoup 1.11.1, with an attempt of parsing for a user's name.

My assumption is that the call is executing the following:

```kotlin
var result = ""
try {
	result = frostJsoup(cookie, FbItem.PROFILE.url).title()
	L.d("Fetch username found", result)
} catch (e: Exception) {
	if (e !is UnknownHostException)
		e.logFrostAnswers("Fetch username failed")
} finally {
	if (result.isBlank() && (name?.isNotBlank() == true)) {
		callback(name!!)
		return@subscribe
	}
	if (name != result) {
		name = result
		saveFbCookie(this@fetchUsername)
	}
	callback(result)
}
```

where cookie is the user's cooke, and the url is touch.facebook.com/me

I'm not sure why this is a seemlingly fatal error though.

As usual, the full log and thread info can be found [here](http://crashes.to/s/92e0e5d0b69)
